content:
Diagnosis:
Right breast cancer - T1bN0M0 small cell variant, diagnosed March 2024
ER/PR strongly positive, HER2 negative

Treatment:
Wide local excision right breast 15 March 2024
Commenced adjuvant letrozole 2.5mg daily April 2024

Current situation:
Review at 3 months post-surgery and 6 weeks into endocrine therapy

I was very pleased to see [redacted name] today who is adapting well to her treatment journey. She has shown remarkable resilience throughout her initial diagnosis and surgical recovery period. The surgical site has healed beautifully with minimal scarring, and she reports being very satisfied with the cosmetic outcome.

She has been taking letrozole regularly for the past 6 weeks and describes mild but manageable side effects. She experiences occasional hot flushes, particularly at night, but these are not significantly impacting her sleep. She has noticed some mild joint stiffness in her hands in the mornings which typically improves with gentle movement. Her mood remains positive and she continues with her regular walking routine, managing 30 minutes daily which she finds helps with the joint symptoms.

On examination today, the right breast surgical site shows excellent healing with no concerning features. There is no lymphadenopathy in either axilla. She has maintained her weight at 65kg.

I have explained that these initial side effects are quite common and often improve over the first few months of treatment. We will continue with the current dose of letrozole as she is managing well overall. I have provided written information about managing hot flushes and joint symptoms, and encouraged her to maintain her current level of physical activity.

We will arrange a follow-up appointment in 3 months' time to review her progress, though she understands to contact us sooner if she develops any concerning symptoms or if the side effects become more troublesome.

Mild hot flushes and morning joint stiffness from letrozole
Continuing letrozole 2.5mg daily at current dose
